div.head: Bibliography
div.p: In addition to the approaches outlined in Section 9.5 for learning ensemble filters and smoothers, the concept of learning from different realizations of the observed data to amortize the cost of inference has become popular in various time-series models. Starting from the variational auto-encoding framework [247] that operationalized amortization in the machine learning community, neural architectures specifically for nonlinear filtering and smoothing via amortized variational inference were considered in [255,240]. [45,188] explored applications of this approach to hierarchical decision-making and model-based reinforcement learning. In addition, the related Neural Process framework in [166,167] learns to map sets of time-series observations to variational distributions for probabilistic inference after training on a family of stochastic processes. Among classical data assimilation algorithms, learning 4DVar was considered in [150]. For work on learning controllers, a subject closely related to learning data assimilation algorithms in the presence of model error, see [146,121]. The use of reinforcement learning within data assimilation is an area likely to see considerable growth; see [311,194]. Approaches based on transportation of measure have shown recent promise in generalizing classic Kalman approaches and reducing their bias when applied to non-Gaussian problems. In particular, the paper [394] introduces the approach of composing triangular transports as in Theorem 10.11 to build prior-to-posterior maps.

We conclude with some remarks on implementation issues that may arise when solving the optimization problems in this chapter. In order to evaluate the variational inference objective J(ùúÉ) in Section 10.2, the expectations can be replaced by empirical means. Additionally, the KL divergence must be computed. In some cases, such as with Gaussian densities, a closed form of the divergence is available: see Example 11.35, and identity (11.18) in particular. Indeed Gaussian approximation is, in general, popular both because the interpretability of the mean and covariance, and because of the closed form for the divergence. In case only samples of ùëû ùëå ‚Ä† ùúÉ are available (such as in an ensemble smoother), the divergence may be approximated by first applying density estimation to these samples. Finally, with all of the considered learning problems, the derivatives of J(ùúÉ) will generally be hard to obtain analytically. In this case, auto-differentiation can be applied, and then gradient-based methods used to minimize it. An example of using auto-differentiation in a similar context is provided in [276].

Note that propriety does not guarantee an accurate ranking of forecast distributions if the forecast distributions are evaluated on verifications with different levels of noise. To ensure this property, the scoring rule must be modified for each level of noise such that the expected score is the same as it would be if there were no noise. A scoring rule possessing this property is known as unbiased.

div.head: Bibliography
div.p: The paper [171] constitutes a readable introduction to study of metrics, and other distance-like functions, including divergences, on the set of probability measures. The explicit formula for the Wasserstein distance between Gaussians in Example 11.9 can be found in [339]; for the KL and ùúí 2 divergence formulae in Example 11.35, see [378] and [375] respectively. The subject of optimal transport, and resulting metrics, is covered in several texts, including [339,426]. For the Euclidean norm metric d(ùëß, ùë¢) = |ùëß -ùë¢| on R ùëë , and for ùúå being absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure (it has a probability density function), there exists an optimal transport coupling in (11.6) solving the Kantorovich formulation of the Wasserstein-ùëù optimal transport problem. Moreover, this coupling has the form in (11.5), which is induced by an optimal transport map ùëî ‚ãÜ solving the corresponding Monge problem (11.4); see [147,Chapter 2] for this connection in the static setting under conditions on the measures and the cost function, as well as [48] for this connection in dynamic setting, which seeks a flow to define the transport map. Note that for ùëù > 1 the objective in (11.6) is strictly convex, and so the optimal transport map that solves ùëä ùëù (ùúå, ùúö) is also unique; however uniqueness does not extend to ùëù = 1; see Section 2.2 of [371] for an example of lack of uniqueness of optimal transport maps for ùëù = 1. See also [371,Section 2.2] for discussion of the optimality of the transport map used in the proof of Lemma 11.10.

The ùúí 2 divergence arises naturally in the analysis of sampling algorithms that involve weighting samples according to the ratio between two densities. In that context, the ùúí 2 divergence has a natural interpretation as quantifying the variance of the weights. The KL divergence has a distinguished place among f-divergences due to its appealing analytical and computational properties. The paper [103] contains proof of the assertion made in Remark 11.36.

div.head: Time-Series Forecasting
div.p: This chapter is devoted to the study of time series forecasting, with an emphasis on data-driven approaches. In most other chapters we have used ùëõ to index data and ùëó to index (discrete) time in (possibly stochastic) dynamical systems. In this chapter the two are conflated as the data comes from a time series as follows:

For this reason the (possibly stochastic) dynamical systems in this chapter will be indexed by ùëõ, not ùëó. Our focus in this chapter is to learn models that are consistent with the data in Data Assumption 14.1 and which may be used to predict future outcomes from points not in the data set. The first set of models we use are deterministic. In Section 14.1 we study analog forecasting methods, a deterministic forecasting methodology that seeks to predict from a given point by looking at what happened, in the data set, starting at nearby point(s). In Section 14.2 we look at fitting Markovian deterministic models to the data; we also study non-Markovian deterministic models, using a recurrent structure to capture memory dependence. In Section 14.3 we introduce linear autoregressive models, modelling the data as a Gaussian process. Section 14.4 introduces non-Gaussian autoregressive models, generalizing the content of Section 14.3 to a non-Gaussian setting using transport ideas. We conclude in Section 14.5 with bibliographic remarks.

div.head: Analog Forecasting
div.p: Assume that we are given time-series data set as in Data Assumption 14.1. The goal of forecasting is to predict ùë£ ùëû given ùë£ 0 , for ùëû ‚àà N. Analog forecasting specifically operates by predicting, from given specific point ùë£ 0 , by looking for nearby points in the data set and using the evolution, in the data set, from those nearby points, to construct a forecast.
